The Bush administration last week ordered an outside panel of experts to consider the long-term direction of America's space program. Most of NASA's problems, according to Logsdon, are not of NASA's making. ``They are the reflection of the country not lowering its expectations at the same time it lowers the budget,'' he said. In fiscal 1964, as the agency busily prepared for the Apollo moon landings, NASA's $5.1 billion budget represented a record 3.85 percent of the federal budget. NASA's budget for the current fiscal year is $12.3 billion, not quite 1 percent of the federal budget. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration is requesting $15.1 billion for fiscal 1991, which begins Oct. 1. That's 1.09 percent of the federal budget. ``The agency has learned to lie to itself about what it can do'' with the available resources, Logsdon said. ``The feeling is if there's total honesty, they'll lose even more political support and priority and have an even smaller budget.'' NASA officials are quick to point out the trouble with Hubble is totally different from the shuttle problems, all but unavoidable in such a complex craft. ``It doesn't mean when you fail that you're no good at managing. It means that's the nature of this business,'' NASA Administrator Richard Truly said during a congressional hearing last week. Technicians tightened most of the 48 bolts on Atlantis' leaky fuel line on Friday in a last-ditch attempt to correct the leak at the launch pad. If no leaks are detected when liquid hydrogen is pumped into Atlantis' external tank Wednesday, NASA will attempt to launch the shuttle with a classified Defense Department payload in mid-August. If Atlantis must be returned to the hangar for repairs, only one shuttle can fly before Discovery's October flight with the sun-probing Ulysses satellite. NASA will either move Columbia back out to the pad for an early September liftoff or give Atlantis a new external tank and try for a mid-September launch. Nine shuttle flights originally were scheduled for 1990. So far, only three missions have been flown, but NASA still hopes to get eight flights finished by year's end. ``Each year we're going to fly more than what we're flying this year. That's the plan,'' Hudkins said. But, he noted, ``We're not going to fly any shuttle before it's time.''

DOC.HEAD: European Leaders To Hold First Talks With New Government
DOC.TEXT: Israel's new right-wing government has its first encounter with European Community leaders this week at a time of increasing European pressure on Israel to move foward with Middle East peace moves. The visit starting Monday by the ``troika'' of EC foreign ministers is to focus on various proposals for resolving the Israelis' standoff with the Palestinians. It comes as Israel is seeking trade concessions from Europe, and European leaders are backing a U.S. peace plan that the government here is resisting. Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir has called for improving relations with Europe. But he admits it won't be easy. ``We have a lot of problems with Europe, and we have to try to explain our positions, straighten out (the problems) and move closer,'' Shamir told reporters last week. At their summit in Dublin in June, European Community leaders renewed their call for an international peace conference that would include participation of the Palestine Liberation Organization, which Israel considers a terrorist organization. Israel refuses any dealings with the PLO and has repeatedly rejected an international peace conference, believing such a meeting could force concessions on the Jewish state. After their visit here, the three foreign ministers will travel to Tunis on Tuesday for talks with the Arab League, whose current president is Farouk Kaddoumi, chief of the PLO's political department. The visiting foreign ministers, led by Gianni de Michelis of Italy, are to meet with Shamir and Israeli Foreign Minister David Levy. Italy now holds the rotating presidency of the EC. The troika also includes foreign ministers Gerard Collins of Ireland, whose country last held the presidency, and Jacques Poos of Luxembourg, which will take the post next. It is the first official visit by representatives of the 12-nation European Community since Shamir formed his right-wing government in June. J. Gwyn Morgan, the EC delegate to Israel, said in an interview that ``the purpose is to discuss with the new Israeli government ... their ideas about the peace process and the possibility of movement.'' Morgan said the community was coordinating its peace efforts with the United States and that the visit ``was discussed in great detail'' with U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III. Israel has so far rejected Baker's efforts to set up preliminary peace talks with a Palestinian delegation in Cairo as a step toward Israel's own proposal for elections in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. Israel introduced the proposal in May 1989 as a way to choose Palestinians to open talks with Israel on limited autonomy for the occupied territories. But the election idea has become mired in disagreements with Baker, and the new government's emphasis has shifted to another aspect of Israel's plan, which urges neighboring Arab countries to open peace negotiations. European diplomats are skeptical as to whether Israel can improve relations with Arab states until it resolves the 31-month uprising in the occupied territories. The Europeans have been highly critical of Israeli efforts to put down the Palestinian revolt with force. The European Parliament earlier this year called for sanctions against Israel for its handling of the uprising, in which 723 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians. So far, a trade conference has been canceled and a meeting to select new Israeli-European scientific projects has been postponed indefinitely. Israel's goal of expanding trade ties with Europe could be at risk, too. Israel, which has a free-trade agreement with the EC, wants some modifications so it won't be disadvantaged when a unified European market is formed in 1992. It has requested a meeting with community leaders for September, but no date has been set. The Jewish state currently exports about $3.2 billion worth of goods to Europe each year and imports $6.5 billion in European goods. Although Israeli imports represent only a fraction of Europe's trade, Israel's exports to Europe constitute one-third of its total foreign sales.

DOC.HEAD: Foreign Rescuers Stop Search, Toll Exceeds 1,000
DOC.TEXT: Foreign rescuers stopped searching Sunday for more survivors in this earthquake-ravaged city after finding no signs of life in buildings devastated by the temblor. The death toll surpassed 1,000. Several strong aftershocks rocked Baguio and Manila, 130 miles to the south, hampering recovery efforts. Religious services were held outdoors because of fears of more damage. British and other foreign volunteers said they were abandoning the search after failing to find signs of life in the Hyatt Hotel, the last area of Baguio where experts believed there might still be survivors of the July 21 quake. Hopes that some people were still alive at the Hyatt faded after rescuers no longer heard tapping sounds on walls near the hotel basement. British rescuers said they feared the last of the survivors died Saturday when aftershocks shifted the rubble, either crushing victims or depriving them of air. ``There are no sounds at all,'' British team leader Willie McMartin told reporters. ``It means effectively that the person making the sounds has died.'' Asked if he believed anyone was still alive at the Hyatt, McMartin replied: ``No.'' Filipino authorities said they would keep searching for survivors but admitted chances of finding any were slim. ``The analysis of the foreign experts assisting in the rescue operations in Baguio City is that the chances are nil for finding anyone still alive in the wreckage in various buildings in the city,'' a government statement said. ``While we would welcome a continuation of their working with us, we leave it to them whether to continue their operations in Baguio. At any rate for the work they have already done, the Filipino people will be forever grateful.'' The statement said Philippine recovery efforts would continue ``as long as safety warrants.'' Figures released Sunday by the Office of Civil Defense, Red Cross and the Regional Disaster Coordinating Center put the death toll at 1,043 as more bodies were discovered. More than 200 bodies are believed still buried beneath the rubble of nearly 30 buildings damaged in the quake, which measured 7.7 on the Richter scale. Others were believed to have died in scores of landslides across northern Luzon. In Nueva Vizcaya province, a landslide dammed up a river and water was threatening to spill over into nearby villages. President Corazon Aquino's government has been sharply criticized for a slow response to the disaster, and it appeared officials did not want to take the political responsibility for calling off the search. On Sunday, Roman Catholic Masses were said outdoors in Baguio's Burnham Park because Bishop Ernesto Salgado said it was too dangerous to worship inside the cathedral. Salgado said priests visited collapsed buildings, blessing the bodies of those who may be entombed there. Jose de Jesus, presidential relief coordinator, said 373 people were killed in Baguio alone and another 175 in the surrounding province of Benguet. De Jesus said 135 people were believed trapped inside eight factories in Baguio but all are believed dead. De Jesus said information on deaths and damage was still trickling in from remote areas, including Nueva Vizcaya province, where many villages and roads were buried by landslides. Philippine pilots who surveyed the areas saw huge columns of survivors walking over the mountains to safety. The pilots described them as loking like ``columns of ants'' silhouetted against the barren mountain slopes.

DOC.HEAD: Baby White Rhinoceros Drowns In Lion Country Canal
DOC.TEXT: A baby white rhinoceros born at the Lion Country Safari attraction drowned in a 4-foot-deep canal just eight days after its birth, park officials said. The 150-pound female rhino drowned July 11, park wildlife director Terry Wolf said Friday. ``For some reason, she tried to cross a canal,'' he said. ``Unfortunately, rhinos aren't very good swimmers and she drowned. There was nothing anybody could have done to prevent it.'' The baby rhino, the 19th born at Lion Country Safari, had been doing well, Wolf said. ``The water situation is always a problem, but the animals need water,'' he said. ``The adults need it to cool off. And the canals also provide drainage for the park.'' A week-old giraffe drowned in another canal on Jan. 4, he said. Another baby rhino drowned in 1983. ``We're evaluating what we can do, but other than lock them up in a corral, there isn't much,'' Wolf said. Isolating animals can cause as many problems as it solves, including interfering with reproduction, he added. ``The fact is that animals drown out in the wild,'' he said. ``They die from lots of other reasons. They die from parasites, from predators, from exposure and from conflicts with others of their own species.'' The white rhino is the most common of five rhino species and is not endangered or threatened, said Wolf.

DOC.HEAD: Finns Watch `Cosmic Light Show'
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Finns and tourists stayed up all night or rose early Sunday to watch a total eclipse of the sun that momentarily darkened the skies over southeastern Finland. Birds suddenly stopped their singing and some flew around aimlessly in panic during the eclipse, which one observer in Helsinki described as ``a cosmic light show, equally frightening and fascinating.'' The total eclipse occurred at 4:52 a.m. (10:52 a.m. EDT). It was visible in an arc about 125 miles wide from the northern Baltic Sea and southeast Finland, across the Kola Peninsula and the northeast Soviet Union, to the Aleutian Islands near Alaska. In Helsinki, the light changed from a summer dawn to dark dusk, and the eerie scene remained for more than a minute. Several thousand people gathered on hills, bridges and rooftops around the city to watch the eclipse. Sightseeing trips on the Gulf of Finland were arranged to provide a better view of the northeast horizon. After the total eclipse the sun became gradually brighter, rising above the clouds on the horizon. People equipped with special glasses or dark film strips could see the silhouette of the moon uncovering the surface of the sun. At 5:45 a.m. (11:45 a.m. EDT) the sun was completely uncovered and many observers began to applaud. Finnair, the national airline, arranged a dozen special flights for eclipse-watchers. Private companies also provided flights. Ten thousand people, 3,000 of them tourists, gathered in Joensuu, 310 miles northeast of Helsinki, where the view was best. The Ursa Astronomical Association and Helsinki University said they planned to perform experiments on the effect of the eclipse on animals and plants. Finnish scientists also said they planned to carry out experiments on gravity. It was the fourth total eclipse visible in Finland during this century. The last one was in 1945 and the next will be in the year 2126.

DOC.HEAD: Ecuadoran President Arrives For Talks With Bush
DOC.TEXT: The president of Ecuador arrived in Washington Sunday to discuss with President Bush his plan for creating a hemisphere-wide free-trade zone. Rodrigo Borja is the first Latin American head of state to meet with Bush since Bush's announcement last month that the United States also will move to increase the flow of capital into Latin American nations. Bush said the effort is designed to further ease the region's foreign debt burden and promote market-oriented economies. Bush is planning a September visit to Brazil, Chile, Argentina, Uruguay and Venezuela. U.S. officials say the administration's initiative is needed to build a stronger and more comprehensive economic partnership with Latin America in order to support what is regarded as a process of democratic change and growing economic realism there. Analysts also view the move as a U.S. effort to counter the creation of a strong European economic bloc lead by West Germany and the increasing economic expansion of Japan in Asia. Borja will meet Monday with Bush and separately with officials of the World Bank, International Monetary Fund, and Inter-American Development Bank. Borja, who was invited by Bush, said after arriving that he brought with him no specific requests. He is expected to explore in full Bush's trade initiative in separate meetings with Secretary of State James A. Baker III, Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady and U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills. The United States is involved in talks with Mexico that could lead to a free trade with that country agreement similar to the one negotiated during the Reagan administration with Canada. The Colombian Embassy here announced last Friday that the U.S. had ``signed a framework agreement with Colombia with a view to establishing bilateral negotiations aimed at creating a free-trade zone between the two countries.'' Undersecretary of the Treasury David Mulford told Congress last Thursday that Bush envisions ``a hemisphere-wide open trade system that links all the Americas.'' The achievement of an agreement with Mexico, Mulford added, ``will be a gigantic step forward. ``As we have seen in the case of Canada, these agreements can offer significant and lasting benefits to both sides,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Lenin Statues Are Being Toppled, Vandalized, And Now Sold
DOC.TEXT: In unprecedented attacks on the Soviet Union's most sacred icon, vandals are defacing and toppling statues of Vladimir Lenin, and one city is even relegating its statue to the ultimate capitalist fate: selling it to the highest bidder. Weekend reports in the state-run media said statues of the Soviet founder have been toppled in two dozen towns in the southern republic of Georgia, ``barbarously disfigured'' in Lithuania and, to the outrage of local Communists, dismantled and put up for sale in the Ukraine city of Ternopol. All the incidents came in republics that have active independence movements and growing nationalistic sentiment. Under President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's reforms, past Soviet leaders like Josef Stalin and Leonid I. Brezhnev have been denounced in the official press, and monuments and plaques in their honor have been taken down. Lenin is still officially lionized. But that doesn't mean all Soviet citizens hold him sacred. In the Georgian capital of Tbilisi, police are guarding the Lenin statue in the city's central square around the clock to keep it from suffering the same fate as a bronze monument that was toppled near the Zemo-Avchalskaya hydroelectric station in another part of town, the newspaper Soviet Culture reported Saturday. ``He was lying looking at me with his frightening, empty eyes, the creator of my motherland, U.S.S.R. _ Vladimir Lenin,'' wrote correspondent S. Babayev of the toppled statue. He added that the plant's labor committee decided to destroy the statue. In recent weeks, monuments to the Soviet founder were destroyed in the Georgian towns of Kodzhori, Kutaisi, Batumi and about two dozen others. Attempts were made to topple them in the Azerbaijan capital of Baku and the Armenian capital of Yerevan, Soviet Culture reported. In the small town of Varniai in northwestern Lithuania, meanwhile, a statue of Lenin in the central square was ``barbarously disfigured'' on Saturday, the official Tass news agency reported. The day was the 50th anniversary of the declaration of Soviet power in the three Baltic republics, which are trying to break away from Moscow. Tass didn't say exactly what was done to the statue, but called it a ``crude provocation.'' It said representatives of a ``local extremist group, the League for Freedom of Lithuania'' claimed responsibility. Official criticism of Lenin is not unheard of. In the spring, a bust of him was removed from the chambers of the City Council in Moscow, where radical reformers won local elections earlier this year. And one critic suggested this year that his body be removed from its Red Square mausoleum and buried. But such attacks were rare. In Ternopol, about 200 miles west of Kiev, the City Council voted 64-0 with 21 abstentions to remove the statues of Lenin and Karl Marx from the central square and sell them, according to the newspaper Rural Life. It quoted Ternopol's local party ideologist, Yelena N. Sosnitskaya. City officials also decided to take down statues of Yaroslav Galan, who fought against Ukrainian nationalism, and Vladimir Zatonsky, a prominent Soviet Communist Party figure, Tass reported. Several military monuments are also to be scrapped, it said. Mrs. Sosnitskaya told Rural Life that orthodox Communists were ``frightened and indignant'' over the decision to take down and sell the Lenin statue. ``I told them (the city council) that `You have the Bolshevism syndrome,''' she said. ``If we start breaking and destroying, how will it all end?'' She said the move to tear down statues of Lenin and Marx could have been caused by authorities' failures to put up monuments to those who helped ``the national rebirth'' of the Ukraine. Honoring Ukrainian heroes is all very well, she said, but that doesn't mean the likes of Marx and Lenin should be tossed aside. ``We supported the decision of deputies to put up monuments to those who really contributed to our area, but as to the dismantling, we consider it an act of vandalism and barbarism,'' she said. Mrs. Sosnitskaya told Rural Life she hoped the Lenin statue could be saved by invoking laws protecting ``cultural monuments.'' Tass quoted an unidentified city council representative as saying only a court decision or a referendum could save the statues. If the sale goes ahead, Mrs. Sosnitskaya said the statues would be sold to ``whatever organizations are interested.'' Asked if there are interested buyers, she replied: ``There are,'' but did not identify them. Removing the statues would cost about $480,000, Mrs. Sosnitskaya said. But, she said: ``We still hope it won't happen.''

DOC.HEAD: The AP
Rape Victim Demands AIDS Tests of Four Defendants
DOC.TEXT: Four defendants in the rape and beating of a 79-year-old woman will be tested for AIDS in what may be the first use of a new state law that allows a rape victim to demand tests of the accused. ``This is certainly the first case I've heard,'' said Stephen Kindland of the state Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services' AIDS prevention headquarters in Tallahassee. Circuit Judge Burton C. Easton agreed Friday to allow the tests under the law that took effect July 1. The test results will not be admissible as evidence if the case comes to trial. Attorneys for the four defendants retained the right to argue against further tests that the state might seek as evidence to compare the results with blood and semen found in the victim's home after the May 9 attack. ``Basically, if the victim wants the tests done, the law allows them to be done,'' said Samuel Williams, who is representing defendant Jeffrey Joseph Digeronimo. ``But the results must be released only to the victim and the defendants, and the tests must be kept confidential.'' The woman and her husband required hospital treatment after the attack. While the tests will tell the victim whether she is at risk now, they will not conclusively answer the question. The tests detect antibodies to the human immunodeficiency virus, which causes AIDS, but Kindland said they don't reach a point of 95 percent reliability until six months after contact. It is likely the victim and defendants will have to undergo subsequent tests before doctors can be conclusive, he said. Digeronimo, 19; Brian Scott Geiger, 18; Robert Dennis Kaczmarek, 21; and Robert Allan Anderson, 16, each are charged with multiple counts of armed burglary, kidnapping and sexual battery from a series of break-ins, including the attack on the elderly woman.

DOC.HEAD: Record Deadlock Brings Tears, Vigil, Government by Lawsuit
DOC.TEXT: Lawmakers, breaking constitutional deadlines in their struggle to resolve a record budget stalemate, are bitterly divided as the courts intervene to order payments to the poor, disabled and the elderly. California's $50 billion budget crisis, an election-year exercise in stubbornness, pits lame-duck Republican Gov. George Deukmejian and the Assembly's Republican caucus against the Legislature's majority Democrats. Assemblywoman Maxine Waters, who grew up on welfare in St. Louis, cried during a floor debate as she recalled her welfare childhood and accused Republicans of saying ``poor children may not eat.'' Assemblyman John Vasconcellos, the budget committee chairman, said he cried while driving home out of hopelessness and embarrassment that ``the richest state in the richest nation in the world's entire history'' is hurting the poor and helpless. Deukmejian and the Republicans maintain that Democrats' unwillingness to live within the state's means would only worsen the fiscal crisis in future years. ``Dog doo'' is what GOP Assemblyman Bill Baker bluntly called a spending plan passed by the state Senate and rejected by the Assembly. ``Dog Doo II, the sequel,'' is what Baker called a similar budget proposal that was mostly the product of Assembly Democrats and was rejected by Assembly Republicans last week. ``This is a Band-Aid solution that covers up the problems for another year,'' said Ross Johnson, the Assembly's Republican leader. The budget for the 1990-91 fiscal year that began July 1 is three weeks overdue with no resolution in sight. Previously, the latest the state had ever passed a budget was July 19. That record was set during the recession of 1983. Unlike 1983, California's economy this year is relatively strong. The problem, as both sides agree, is a $3.6 billion gap between estimated tax revenues and the spending necessary for current services plus increases for inflation and population and to maintain a $1.3 billion emergency reserve. The agreement ends there. Democrats say the problem is caused by exploding populations in costly programs such as public schools, prisons, aid to the elderly and AIDS patients, and by the $29 billion in various tax cuts handed out since 1978. Republicans say the problem is runaway government spending, overly generous welfare programs and a series of initiatives that have forced minimum spending levels for programs such as public schools. Deukmejian and the Legislature's Republicans, particularly those in the Assembly, want the gap closed entirely with cuts, refusing to agree to any tax increases. Democrats say cuts would be too harsh in public health, school, university and mental health programs and want a combination of some cuts and some tax increases. Neither side is willing to budge. Without a budget, state government goes on, but the controller has no authority to pay bills and issue paychecks. However, groups owed money have gone to the federal courts, which through Friday had ordered payment of $688 million in bills for Medi-Cal doctors, hospitals and nursing homes, for welfare mothers, children and for in-home workers. California is not the only state with budget problems this year. The state Senate Office of Research said last week that 24 other states have had gaps between revenues and expenditures. Fifteen states chose to raise taxes to solve the problem. California's bond rating is currently ``AAA,'' the highest possible, from the three major rating houses; some states with budget problems have had their bond ratings lowered. Controller Gray Davis warned, ``I think each day we go without a budget, we run the risk of annoying the credit rating agencies.'' As the budget standoff continues, many groups have staged rallies and sit-ins in the Capitol. About four dozen people in wheelchairs have been arrested in a series of demonstrations in the governor's office this month. Vasconcellos, a Democrat, brought three welfare mothers and their nine children to the Capitol and asked Deukmejian to meet with them and explain why he wants to freeze their benefits. The governor declined. Despite the crisis, the Capitol this weekend was nearly empty. The Senate passed a budget proposal on July 10 and went home until the Assembly acts. The Assembly rejected a second budget proposal Thursday and adjourned for the weekend. The Capitol is deserted, that is, except for one legislator. Democratic Assemblyman Norman Waters began a vigil Friday in the Assembly chambers. Waters, who faces a tough re-election race in November, said he'll sit there alone until the budget crisis is solved because ``compromise can't happen if people don't bother to show up.'' Waters could have a long wait. Assemblywoman Waters, who is not related, said during floor debate, ``It will be a cold day in hell before I participate in a society giving up on its children.'' Republican Assemblyman Chris Chandler said he partially agreed with her: ``There are many of us over here who are prepared to stay here until hell freezes over.''

DOC.HEAD: Racism at Root of Indian Clashes in Canada, Mohawks Say
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 14 grafs to UPDATE with train to carry commuters past blockade, ADDS population of towns, reservations, CORRECTS date of shootout in Oka to July 11, sted 12. Pickup 14th, `About 1,000...' ^By DAVID GERMAIN
DOC.TEXT: Mohawk Indians embroiled in a land war with the United States and Canada claim 300 years of racism are at the root of their quarrel. Government negotiators say it has nothing to do with race. They say the latest clash, which left one person dead, stems from the Mohawks' impatience with the government to resolve land disputes. The death of two Mohawks in May involved an Indian dispute over gambling. ``Many of our ancestors have died because they've trusted the white government,'' said Grand Chief Joe Norton of the Kahnawake Mohawk Reservation south of Montreal. The reservation, home to 6,000 Indians, has been closed by police and Indian blockades since July 11, when police stormed a Mohawk barricade at the nearby Kanesatake reserve, where 750 Mohawks live, near Oka, Quebec. Indians there have blocked roads for four months to stop a golf course expansion project on land they claim is Mohawk ancestral territory. A Quebec provincial police officer died in a shootout between police and Indians at Oka. Experts are trying to determine if the bullet that killed him was fired by an Indian or a fellow officer during the wild shootout. The uneasy standoff between Indians and police continued Sunday in the small town of Oka and around Kahnawake. Negotiations between the Mohawks and Canadian officials broke off last week and no new talks are scheduled. ``This is a settler country,'' said Loran Thompson, spokesman for Mohawks at the Oka barricade. ``People came in and settled our land, we let them, and then they took it away.'' In the 17th century, Jesuit missionaries who tried to convert Mohawks and other tribes in the Iroquois Confederacy called the Indians ``pagans and savages,'' Thompson said. Canadians and Americans still view Indians as an inferior race, he claimed. The Quebec Human Rights Commission Saturday issued a statement deploring the ``increase in racial intolerance and the multiplication of racial incidents'' around Mohawk territory. Last week, mobs in Chateauguay, a city of 40,000 people on the southern border of Kahnawake burned Mohawks in effigy, taunted Indians at a barricade with war whoops and yelled, ``Damn savages!'' Chateauguay residents are angry over the Mohawk blockade of the Mercier Bridge over the St. Lawrence River north of the reservation. Commuters use the bridge to reach jobs in Montreal. Their 30-minute commute now takes up to two hours because they have to cross the river at another bridge. On Sunday, Canadian officials announced that beginning Monday a special train will carry commuters to Montreal in a one-hour trip. About 1,000 people gathered outside the barricades in Chateauguay on Saturday night, the smallest crowd all week. Two men carried a banner showing a Mohawk in feathers and other Indian regalia. A circle was painted around the caricature with a slash through the Indian's face. ``The Indian people have always been looked upon as less than human,'' said Thompson, a member of the militant Mohawk Warriors Society. Members of the group have been accused of inciting violence on Mohawk territory, including the St. Regis Indian Reservation along the U.S.-Canadian border. Two Indians died there in May in a gunfight between opponents and supporters of the reservation's casinos. ``This is a racial war,'' Thompson said, referring to Oka dispute. ``That's what it all comes down to.'' John Bray, a spokesman for Canadian Indian Affairs, said the situation is a dispute between the government and a faction of Canadians who have legitimate land claims. ``This is not a racial war,'' Bray said. ``There's a certain degree of frustration among the Mohawks. It's their perception of how the federal government has not moved as broadly or quickly as the Indian people wish it to be.'' Extremist Mohawks want Canada to give them 5 million acres of land in eastern Canada and the United States to hand over another 9 million acres in New York and New England. The Mohawks now have 10,200 acres at Kahnawake, 28,000 acres at St. Regis, 2,000 at Oka and 700 at the Ganienkeh encampment in northern New York near Plattsburgh. Each Mohawk territory has been blockaded at various times by police in the past four months. Canadian police and New York state troopers continue to occupy St. Regis. At Ganienkeh, a military helicopter made an emergency landing in March after it was hit by gunfire, prompting an 11-day standoff between Indians and police. Chateauguay Mayor Jean-Bosco Bourcier blamed the racial slurs shouted at Mohawks last week on a ``minority of overly excited people.'' Bourcier himself was taunted by a mob of about 2,000 people who marched through the town Friday night. The mob blamed Bourcier and other officials for failing to build a commuter route to Montreal that would bypass the reservation. Some in the crowd yelled racial insults about the Mohawks. ``They're ignorant, they're uneducated, they stink,'' yelled one young man. ``I still have friends on the reservation, but a lot of people in Chateauguay won't stand the Indians any more,'' said town resident Audrey Pepin. Most in the crowd seemed to agree with Bourcier that racism against Mohawks was limited to a handful of people. ``I don't think it's fair to say the people of Chateauguay or Quebec are more racist than any other,'' said Jean Dorion, president of the French Nationalist St. Jean Baptiste Society, a Quebec secessionist group.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands of Romanians Rally For Release of Student Leader
DOC.TEXT: About 5,000 protesters shouted slogans denouncing President Ion Iliescu at a rally Sunday to demand the release of a jailed student activist. The protest _ the second in the capital in two days _ marked the seven-month anniversary of the uprising that led to the toppling of Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. The demonstrators gathered in the Bucharest's Opera Square, many of them carrying flowers. ``Down with Iliescu!'' and ``Down with Communism!'' they shouted. Iliescu, a former Communist official, won free elections in May. But opponents have demanded he step down, saying he has continued many of Ceausescu's policies, if in an attenuated form. The president has repeatedly affirmed his commitment to democracy and a market economy. The jailed student activist, Marian Munteanu, was the leader of a 53-day round-the-clock anti-government rally in Bucharest's University Square that was broken up by police last month. The police were backed by vigilante coal miners summoned to the capital by Iliescu to quell anti-government rioters. Six people were killed and scores injured in the rioting and violence that followed after the University Square protest was broken up. Munteanu was arrested on charges of inciting to violence and remains in detention. Sunday's crowd, made up largely of students, shouted ``Try the miners, not Munteanu!'' A banner read: ``You have not arrested one student, but all students.'' Iliescu, whose National Salvation Front won May 20 elections by a landslide, drew international criticism for the miners' violence and the detention of Munteanu and other opposition leaders. Opposition groups participating in Sunday's rally included the 21 December Association. Its leader, Dumitru Dinca, was also detained after the unrest in June. Iliescu last week said it was up to the prosecutor general to decide whether Munteanu should be released. Premier Petre Roman told French President Francois Mitterrand in Paris last week it was possible Munteanu could be freed.

DOC.HEAD: 12-Foot Boa Constrictor an Uninvited Guest
DOC.TEXT: Bobbie Gross went out to the garage to do laundry and ran into an unexpected visitor _ a 12-foot, 25-pound boa constrictor coiled up on an old air-conditioner. She screamed for her husband. ``He came out thinking it was just going to be a little grass snake,'' she said. The Grosses were so unnerved that Animal Control officer Monica Davis said that when she arrived Saturday she found them standing all the way across the street from their home. Ms. Davis said she thought the snake had just eaten. ``He was real docile and he had a big lump in his middle ... He probably got a cat or a squirrel.'' Ms. Gross said she and her husband now believe noises they heard from the garage Friday night were probably made by the snake moving around. ``We kept hearing these bumps, and we went outside two or three times, but we never saw anything,'' she said. Officials believe the snake is somebody's escaped pet. Ms. Davis took it to an animal farm for safekeeping until its owner is found.

DOC.HEAD: Greg LeMond Captures Third Tour de France Title
DOC.TEXT: American Greg LeMond powered his way to a third Tour de France title Sunday, keeping bicycling's most prestigious crown and erasing any doubt that he is king in a sport long ruled by Europeans. The victory came a day after LeMond rallied to take the lead from Italian Claudio Chiapucci. The Italian finished second in the grueling three-week race. LeMond was in command throughout the day Sunday, taking his second title in a row with relative ease following a dramatic final-day battle with Frenchman Laurent Fignon last year. Cheered by thousands who gathered along Paris' famed Champs Elysees, the 29-year-old cyclist stayed with the rest of the pack Sunday. It was enough for him to preserve his two-minute, 16-second lead over Chiappucci. Dutch rider Eric Breukink finished third, 13 seconds behind Chiappucci. ``The last stage wasn't difficult,'' LeMond said. ``But all day, I was nervous. I didn't want to take chances, but I was impatient to cross the finish line.'' It was the culmination of an exhausting 2,112-mile odyssey around France. LeMond has now competed in five Tours, placing in the top three finishers each time. His 1986 victory made him the first American to win the race. He missed the next two years, in large part because of a near-fatal hunting accident. However, he scored a roaring comeback last year by squeaking past Fignon by only eight seconds on the final day. LeMond, a native of Wayzata, Minn., was asked on French television Sunday if he was trying to match the record of five Tour de France victories co-held by two Frenchmen. ``It's always a dream, but not something I live for, because in 1986 I learned that life changes quickly,'' he answered in fluent French. ``I won in '86, but the next year I almost died,'' he said, referring to when he was accidentally shot. ``Things can change just as quickly in the future. You never know. But if I could win every year, I wouldn't say no.''

DOC.HEAD: Rushdie Revenge Film Banned in Britain
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 7th graf, ``They say...' to UPDATE with comment from Rushdie defense committee. Pickup pvs 8th graf, `James Ferman...'
DOC.TEXT: British authorities have banned a Pakistani film which portrays author Salman Rushdie as a killer and torturer of Moslems who is finally slain himself, a published report said Sunday. Rushdie, a British subject born into a Moslem family in India, has been in hiding under guard since February 1989 because of an Iranian death threat. Many Moslems considered his novel, ``The Satanic Verses,'' blasphemous. The British Board of Film Classification refused to license distribution of the film because police advised that it could be criminally libelous, the Independent on Sunday newspaper reported. The film, titled ``International Guerrillas,'' portrays Rushdie as the agent of an Jewish conspiracy against Islam. The 3{-hour film depicts him killing and torturing Moslems until he himself is killed by a bolt of lightning. Mohammed Fayyaz, who owns worldwide distribution rights to the film, said banning it amounted to ``double standards.'' ``They say this is an independent country, but they ban a film which gives the real feeling of Moslems,'' the newspaper quoted Fayyaz as saying. A spokeswoman for the Salman Rushdie Defense Committee said Rushdie believes the film ``should be in the public domain so that any libel or offense may be dealt with according to the due process of law.'' Committee spokeswoman Frances D'Souza also said it was ``debatable'' whether the film would expose Rushdie to increased danger. ``It is also debatable whether the majority of British Moslems would condone, let alone support, its message,'' she said. James Ferman, director of the film classification board, told Fayyaz the film could be licensed if the Rushdie character were given a different name and all speeches calling for his death were excised. ``This would turn it into a more traditional entertainment, with a villain who is an enemy of Islam in a general sense, rather than a specifically named individual,'' The Independent on Sunday quoted the letter as saying. Lawmakers weighed in on both sides of the issue. Max Madden, a Labor Party lawmaker who has been calling on Rushdie to cancel any further editions of the book, said Sunday that the ban would ``bewilder and confuse many Moslems who were unable to go to any court to try to ban `The Satanic Verses.''' ``It is further evidence of the need for the government to clarify the law about the publication of any material thought capable of inciting relgious, racial or personal hatred,'' he said. Conservative lawmaker Anthony Beaumont-Dark, though, said the banning was ``absolutely right.'' ``Anything that incites people to violence should be banned _ and I am not a great banner of anything,'' Beaumont-Dark said. ``Surely everybody, Moslems included, must be against incitement to violence.'' Rushdie's publisher announced earlier this month that two new books by him would soon be brought out. They will be his first since ``The Satanic Verses'' brought death threats from the late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini. Granta Books, in association with Penguin Books, said it had acquired world English-language rights to Rushdie's novel, ``Haroun and the Sea of Stories,'' and to ``Imaginary Homelands,'' a collection of essays. The novel will be published in Britain on Sept. 27 and in the United States next year. The death threats against Rushdie have hampered restoration of diplomatic ties between Tehran and London, which were effectively severed in June 1987 after a series of expulsions of diplomats.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 1st item in People package to CORRECT ``Golden Girls'' network to NBC, sted CBS. For Release 6 p.m. EDT
DOC.TEXT: Rue McClanahan of NBC's ``Golden Girls'' says she's finally kicked her addiction to men. The five-time bride boasts in the July 28 issue of TV Guide magazine that she has gone five years without a serious relationship. ``It was a quiet kind of desperation,'' said the 55-year-old actress. ``I always thought I had to have a man.'' Ms. McClanahan first married in 1958, a year after she graduated from the University of Tulsa. She received her fifth divorce in 1985, about the same time she won the role of Blanche Devereaux on ``Golden Girls.'' ``Playing Blanche changed my life more than anything,'' she said. ``It helped raise my self-esteem, because Blanche is convinced she's terrific. And no matter what happens to her, she always bounces back.''

DOC.HEAD: Pepper Commission: Government Should Make Medicare Changes
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs 3rd graf to restore dropped matter ``voted''
DOC.TEXT: A bipartisan commission on Sunday said the government should help the elderly poor pay Medicare charges, add coverage of preventive services to Medicare and order improvements in supplementary insurance coverage. The $2.8 billion package recommended by the Pepper Commission would add to a $66 billion plan the panel suggested in March that would provide health care coverage to nearly all Americans. The panel voted 11-4 for the latest three recommendations. ``People may think that because the elderly have Medicare they are adequately protected. That's wrong,'' Sen. Jay Rockefeller, D-W.Va., commission chairman, said in the panel's announcement of the action. The improvements are ``desperately needed to assure older Americans the same minimum standard of protection we've already recommended providing Americans under 65,'' he said. The panel, created by Congress in 1988 as the U.S. Bipartisan Commission on Comprehensive Health Care, includes 12 members of Congress and three White House appointees. It was later renamed to honor the late Rep. Claude Pepper, D-Fla. The commission's larger package of proposals in March was criticized by some of its own members for failing to recommend funding. In its earlier action, the panel split 8-7 on the plan to achieve universal access by requiring businesses to provide private health insurance to their workers or to contribute to a public plan for employees and non-working dependents. At that time, panel members also voted 11-4 for a plan offering all Americans coverage for long-term care in their homes and for the first three months in a nursing home. The same four who voted against that plan also voted against the latest recommendations: Rep. Willis Gradison Jr., R-Ohio; Rep. Fortney ``Pete'' Stark, D-Calif.; John F. Cogan, a senior fellow at the Hoover Institute in Palo Alto, Calif.; and Rep. Thomas Tauke, R-Iowa. The vote was taken by mail or telephone over the past week, commission spokesman Philip Shandler said. Stark opposed the latest recommendations for the same reason he voted against the earlier ones _ because the panel didn't propose a way to pay, his spokesman said. The first recommendation would help the near-poor elderly pay for Medicare premiums and deductibles. Those people are the 8.2 million elderly whose incomes are between the poverty level _ $6,280 per year for an individual _ and 200 percent of poverty, or $12,560. The 3.5 million people over 65 whose incomes are below the poverty line currently are helped _ or will be when the program is completely phased in by 1992 _ by Medicaid picking up the Medicare premiums and deductibles. The panel also recommended the extension of Medicare coverage to screening tests for early detection of breast, colon and prostate cancer. Other preventive services would be added to Medicare coverage ``when they are determined to be effective relative to cost,'' the commission said. The commission also recommended new federal standards for Medigap insurance policies that are intended to supplement Medicare coverage. These standards would require insurers to use more of their premium revenue for benefits, prohibit insurers from refusing to sell coverage based on health status and limit commissions for new policies. Insurers also would be required to develop simpler policies that are easier to understand and that would be standard throughout the industry.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 4th item in People package to CORRECT to `Lloyd Webber,' sted `Webber' on second reference in 2nd and penultimate grafs.
DOC.TEXT: A composer has filed a lawsuit accusing Andrew Lloyd Webber of stealing the music for the theme of ``The Phantom of the Opera.'' Attorneys for Ray Repp, 48, a composer and music publisher from Trumansburg, N.Y., filed a copyright infringement suit last week in federal court in Chicago, where a production of the hit musical is playing and where Lloyd Webber is expected to visit, the Chicago Sun-Times reported Saturday. Repp told the newspaper Thursday that he first heard the score for the ``Phantom'' a few months ago and was startled by the similarity between it and his own 1978 copyright song, ``Till You.'' ``Bar for bar, measure for measure, it was my song,'' Repp said. Telephones went unanswered Saturday at the London office of Lloyd Webber's production company, the Really Useful Group PLC, and at the administrative office of the Auditorium Theater in Chicago, where ``Phantom'' is playing. About 13,000 recordings of ``Till You'' and about 23,000 copies of the sheet music have been sold since 1978, said Repp.

DOC.HEAD: Officials: Mega Borg A Hazard During Hurricane Season
DOC.TEXT: The crippled supertanker Mega Borg, dead in the water in the Gulf of Mexico, is still a threat to the environment because it could be torn apart during a hurricane, the Coast Guard says. ``We're in the hurricane season now, and we could get weather that could break it loose,'' said Cmdr. Frank Whipple, executive officer at the Coast Guard's Marine Safety Office in Galveston. Debris from the ship, and the traces of residual oil left in it, pose the biggest threat to the environment should a hurricane strike, officials said. An explosion on the Norwegian tanker June 8 killed four crew members, and over the next few days the burning ship spewed some 3.9 million gallons of crude oil into the gulf. It remains 57 miles offshore from Galveston, but is due to be towed to Pakistan in a few weeks. The vessel was sold for scrap to Aylesford LTD of Gibralter for about $2.4 million, said a spokesman for the Houston law firm of Eastham, Watson, Dale & Forney, which represents the owner.

DOC.HEAD: British Physician Begins Voyage to Retrace Steps of Marco Polo
DOC.TEXT: A British physician left Hong Kong for Shanghai Sunday in a replica of a 13th-century Chinese vessel to retrace the voyage of Marco Polo on his return home from China. The Chinese ``were once the emperors of the sea...(and) this voyage is setting out to prove it,'' said Dr. Wayne Moran, 38. He said he would try to pinpoint places vaguely described by Marco Polo to ``piece together the jigsaw puzzle of his sea route.'' Moran, who lives in Cardiff, Wales, plans to return to Hong Kong in September after sailing to several Chinese ports. He then plans to sail to Malaysia, Sri Lanka, Iran, Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Turkey and Greece on a voyage that will end in Italy. The 76-foot junk, Cocachin, took six years to build and cost about $640,000. It is decorated with intricate Chinese carvings. The 75-ton vessel is named after the Mongol princess Marco Polo escorted to Iran, then Persia, for her wedding. The boat has modern communication equipment. Moran designed the junk from information culled from historical engravings and descriptions fed into a computer. Marco Polo, the 13th Century Venetian trader, sailed home to Italy after serving for 17 years in various posts in the court of the Mongol ruler Kublai Khan. Moran is accompanied by his wife, three children and a crew of 13. He said he will set the date for the final leg of his voyage after he returns to Hong Kong.

DOC.HEAD: Showers And Thunderstorms In Eastern U.S.
DOC.TEXT: More rain was scattered across the eastern half of the nation Sunday after a night of stormy weather, and temperatures fell to record lows from the Rockies to the Plains. Showers and thunderstorms developed in the warm, humid air ahead of a stationary front curving through the south-central and eastern states, and along a stationary front extending from southwestern Texas to eastern Oklahoma. Showers and thunderstorms formed over much of the Gulf Coast and from the Southeast to the lower Great Lakes. In the cooler air north of the first stationary front, scattered showers fell from the upper Mississippi Valley to New England. Heavier rainfall in the 24 hours up to 8 a.m. EDT included 2.78 inches at Paducah, Ky.; 2.74 inches at Peoria, Ill.; 2.56 inches at Springfield, Ill., and 2.45 inches at Columbia, Mo. Afternoon temperatures reached only the 60s and upper 50s over the central High Plains. Overnight lows dipped below 60 from northern New England to the upper Mississippi Valley, and into the 40s and 50s in the northern and central Plains. Record lows were 37 degrees in Cheyenne, Wyo.; 49 in Denver, a tie; 44 in Dickinson, N.D., a tie; 43 in Great Falls, Mont., a tie; and 46 in North Platte, Neb. Sunday's low for the Lower 48 states was 37 degrees in Laramie, Wyo., and West Yellowstone, Mont. On Saturday, thunderstorm winds gusted to 62 mph at El Paso International Airport in southwestern Texas, to 69 mph at the small Deer Valley Airport in north-central Phoenix, and to 70 mph at the Marion Williamson Airport in southern Illinois. The storm in Phoenix downed hundreds of utility poles and left up to 50,000 customers in the dark at the height of the storm, said Wayne Kaplan of Arizona Public Service Co. A Salt River Project official said about 15,000 customers of that utility also lost service. About 200 customers were still without service Sunday morning, Kaplan said. The storm knocked Phoenix radio station KOOL off the air for an extended period, and lightning that hit the roof of Phoenix Newspapers Inc. in downtown Phoenix left it without news wire services for about three hours, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Nick Faldo Wins British Open
DOC.TEXT: Briton Nick Faldo took his second British Open golf crown Sunday, beating American Payne Stewart by five strokes and finishing two shots off the tournament record. Stewart finished in a tie for second with Mark McNulty of Zimbabwe. It was the second British Open title for Faldo, 33. He won the British Open in 1987. On Sunday, he shot a one-under par 71. He finished the tournament 18-under par 270. Faldo, winner of the last two Masters, had nine consecutive pars midway through the round to hold off a charge by Stewart. Faldo had three birdies and two bogeys Sunday. His performance was only slightly less consistent than in 1987, when his 18 pars in the final round helped him claim his first British Open title at Muirfield. Calm weather throughout the weekend removed the teeth from the oldest course in the world. The sea breezes that often turn routine shots into adventures were mild, allowing golfers to shoot straight at the pin on many holes. Stewart, winner of the 1989 PGA Championship winner, made a run at Faldo but could get no closer than two strokes after his fourth birdie on the 12th hole. Stewart finished in a tie for second at 13-under 275 with McNulty, who had the best round of the day, a seven-under par 65. Jodie Mudd shot 66 and tied for fourth with Ian Woosnam of Wales at 276. Faldo started the day at 199, the lowest 54-hole mark in British Open history. But he failed by two strokes to match Tom Watson's tournament record of 268 set at Turnberry in 1977. Faldo, who won the U.S. Masters in April and came within a stroke of making a playoff at the U.S. Open in June, had 67, 65 and 67 in his first three rounds on the par-72 Old Course.

DOC.HEAD: Hezbollah Repels Offensive By PLO, Amal Militia
DOC.TEXT: Iranian-backed fundamentalists Sunday crushed a joint attack by rival Shiite Moslems and Palestinian guerrillas, capping two days of close-quarter combat at a mountaintop town in south Lebanon, police said. A police spokesman said 52 people were killed and 135 wounded in the ferocious battle that turned the town of Jarjou into a ``graveyard littered with uncollected corpses.'' The spokesman, who cannot be identified in line with standing regulations, said the casualty toll would rise sharply when rescuers are allowed to go into Jarjou, the largest town in south Lebanon's Iqlim al-Tuffah, or Apple Province. The new casualties raised the toll of the weeklong clashes between the pro-Iranian Hezbollah, or Party of God, and the more secular Syrian-backed to 125 killed and 367 wounded. The two factions have been fighting each other intermittently for three years for leadership of the 1.2 million Shiites who make up Lebanon's largest sect. By police count, at least 1,166 people have been killed and 4,009 wounded in the power struggle. In a statement, Amal accused Hezbollah's fighters of booby-trapping corpses in Jarjou. It said one Amal militiaman was killed when the explosive-laden body of a comrade exploded as he tried to remove it from the battlefront Sunday evening. Iran has stepped in to try to arrange a cease-fire. Allam Riza Walizadeh, political officer of the Iranian embassy in Beirut, traveled to the southern city of Sidon for meetings with factional leaders Sunday. A Hezbollah communique Sunday claimed to have ``regained the whole of Jarjou from Amal and the mercenaries.'' Amal denied the claim, saying it still held a quarter of Jarjou. But police and reporters said Amal and PLO fighters had withdrawn from the town. The term ``mercenaries'' appeared to be an allusion to a 600-member force of Palestine Liberation Organization guerrillas that was deployed in the region ostensibly to halt the latest round of Amal-Hezbollah warfare. Police said the PLO force, drawn mainly from Yasser Arafat's Fatah mainstream faction, became actively involved on Amal's side after a series of grenade-throwing Hezbollah assaults that killed three guerrillas near Jarjou on Friday. An estimated 250 PLO fighters teamed up with 300 Amal militiamen in a two-pronged storming of Jarjou on Saturday. Hezbollah had taken the town from Amal at the outbreak of the latest round of intra-Shiite fighting on Monday. A police spokesman said the PLO's total casualties since their deployment in the Apple Province on Tuesday stood at nine killed and 23 wounded.

DOC.HEAD: `Mercy Killing' Prosecutor Says He'll Now Support Clemency Bid
DOC.TEXT: The man who five years ago convinced a jury that Roswell Gilbert's slaying of his elderly, ailing wife was murder, not mercy, now wants to help set Gilbert free. ``He should be released,'' says Kelly Hancock, who prosecuted Gilbert but left the state attorney's office in 1989 for his own legal practice. He says he still believes Gilbert, now 81, was wrong in killing his 73-year-old wife Emily. And he says Gilbert agreed last month in a private meeting in prison that the killing was wrong. The state never sought the death penalty, and the only alternative was life in prison with no chance of parole for 25 years. ``I prosecuted the crime,'' Hancock told The Miami Herald in an interview published Sunday. ``I didn't prosecute the man. ``I think it's right to take this stand now. I never thought he should spend 25 years in prison _ which would certainly be a death sentence.'' Mrs. Gilbert was suffering from Alzheimer's diasease and osteoporosis when Gilbert shot her in the head in their suburban condo on March 4, 1985. Gilbert said he killed her to end her suffering. His defense lawyer told jurors that the killing was ``the greatest act of love you'll ever witness.'' Hancock called it cold-blooded murder. ``Base your decision on the hard, cold facts,'' he told the jury. ``You must follow the law or your verdict will be a miscarriage of justice.'' Hancock said the case has never left his mind since. On June 20, he went to the Lawtey Correctional Facility to talk with Gilbert, who suffers from a variety of ailments, including lung and heart diseases. ``I wanted an opportunity to talk to Roswell, to get to know him on a one-to-one basis, to learn about his background,'' said Hancock. ``I wanted to find out if he thought I was a fair prosecutor.'' Hancock also said he wanted one thing from Gilbert before helping him seek clemency, and he said he got it: Gilbert admitted that what he did was wrong. ``I don't think he's going to get out and say he did the right thing,'' he said. Hancock says the system of justice that worked when it convicted Gilbert of murder will work to win him clemency. ``If his attorney asks me, I will write a letter and state my position to the governor,'' he said. ``If a clemency hearing is held, I will give my opinion at that point.'' Brad Stark, Gilbert's appellate attorney, said he is seeking a September hearing by Gov. Bob Martinez and members of the Florida Cabinet, who sit as the Executive Board of Clemency. Peter Dunbar, the governor's chief legal counsel, noted that the Gilbert case ``has a uniqueness around it'' but said the state receives 12,000 clemency requests a year. He also said the trial judge and the chief prosecutor, not just the trial prosecutor, would have a say if a hearing is granted.

DOC.HEAD: Jordan Says It Killed Palestinian Guerrilla Infiltrators
DOC.TEXT: Soldiers shot and killed four armed Palestinian guerrillas who infiltrated from Syria, Jordanian officials said Sunday. A police official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the heavily armed guerrillas illegally crossed Jordan's northern border. A military spokesman said the incident occurred late Saturday. The official said the guerrillas carried documents identifying them as members of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command, headed by Ahmed Jibril. The group is based in Damascus, Syria. Mustafa Khmyes, a member of the Marxist group's Central Council, denied involvement by his organization. He said the documents carried by the men were probably false. An army spokesman told Jordan's official Petra news agency the guerrillas entered Jordan via an area ``usually used by drug and arms smugglers,'' two miles west of the Ramtha border post. The military spokesman told Petra the guerrillas were killed when ``our men warned them to stop and they did not respond, which forced our army to open fire at them and kill them.'' Jordanian authorities suggested that because the men were carrying heavy weapons, it appeared that they had targets in Jordan rather than using it as a route to Israel. ``Our group did not infiltrate into Jordan and we did not plan any assassinations in Jordan,'' Khmyes said from Amman. ``We are not responsible for this attack.'' The police official refused to say precisely where the shooting took place. But he said the four were shot ``a few minutes after they actually crossed into Jordanian territory.'' The official said the slain men had four silencer-fitted handguns, 15 hand grenades and four Soviet-made Kalashnikov assault rifles. It was the third recent report of such an infiltration attempt on the Jordanian-Syrian border. In January, Jordan asked Syria to help prevent incursions by Damascus-based Palestinian factions. They have been using Jordanian territory as a path for military attacks against Israel, on Jordan's western border. The Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command opposes Yasser Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, and denounces his recent moderate policy of peace with Israel. The government of Jordan supports Arafat's policies.

DOC.HEAD: Stray Bullet Fells Napping 9-Year-Old
DOC.TEXT: A stray bullet hit a 9-year-old girl in the head early Sunday, critically wounding her while she napped in her family's parked car after they returned to the city after a day at an amusement park. Veronica Corales had stayed in the car with her mother and grandmother while her father and an aunt took two sleeping cousins to their apartment in the East New York section of Brooklyn. Gunfire erupted and a bullet went through the car door. ``I realized after it stopped it was my daughter...'' Deborah Cosme said. ``When I put my hand under her head, I started to see blood coming off her head.'' One man had fired 10 to 12 shots from a 9mm pistol at another man. It wasn't immediately clear what caused the dispute. The shooter ran away. Witnesses later pointed out a man who returned to the scene and said he fired the shots, and police took him into custody. Veronica was in critical condition at Brookdale Hospital with a gunshot wound to the back of the head. Police said Dorian Daughtry, 22, of Brooklyn, was charged with attempted murder and first-degree assault.

DOC.HEAD: Writer Stanley Shapiro, Oscar Winner for `Pillow Talk,' Dead at 65
DOC.TEXT: Oscar-winning screenwriter Stanley Shapiro, whose string of romantic comedies included ``Pillow Talk,'' starring Doris Day and Rock Hudson, has died of leukemia at age 65. Shapiro died Saturday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center, said Dr. Robert Miller, a longtime friend. The New York City native began his writing career in radio and television. He switched to movies, and turned out a string of hits in the 1950s and '60s. His flair for light, romantic comedy provided popular starring vehicles for such actors as Cary Grant, David Niven, Marlon Brando, Charles Boyer and Dean Martin. His screen credits include ``Operation Petticoat,'' ``How to Save a Marriage _ and Ruin Your Life,'' ``The Perfect Furlough'' and ``Come September.'' Shapiro also wrote plays, including, ``The Engagement Baby,'' and the novels ``Simon's Soul'' and ``A Time to Remember.'' His Academy Award-winning ``Pillow Talk'' in 1959, in which a couple who dislike each other fall in love over a party line, was the first pairing of Hudson and Miss Day, who went on to make several other hit movies together. Shapiro's last movie, 1988's ``Dirty Rotten Scoundrels,'' starred Michael Caine and Steve Martin as a pair of con men trying to outdo one another. He is survived by his daughter, Sesquia.

DOC.HEAD: Retired Federal Judge Dead at 80
DOC.TEXT: Retired U.S. District Judge Owen D. Cox, who in the 1970s ordered the busing of thousands of students in the interest of desegregation, has died after a long illness. He was 80. Cox died at a nursing home Saturday night. A longtime local attorney and prominent member of the Republican Party, Cox was appointed to the federal bench in 1970 by President Nixon. Cases he handled during his 10 years on the bench included a desegregation lawsuit against the Corpus Christi Independent School District. In the 1970s, he ordered the busing of thousands of students. Cox was an assistant Texas attorney general in 1942 and Corpus Christi city attorney from 1943 to 1947, except for 20 months of military service during World War II. Survivors include two daughters, a son and three grandchildren. Funeral arrangements were pending.

DOC.HEAD: Suspected Arab Collaborator Killed, Soldiers Shoot 10
DOC.TEXT: A dozen masked Palestinians on Sunday beat to death an alleged collaborator with Israel in Jerusalem. At a refugee camp in the Israeli-occupied Gaza Strip, 10 Palestinian teen-agers were shot and wounded by soldiers in a third day of violence there, Arab sources said. In the occupied West Bank, 30 Israelis demanding the right to build a Jewish settlement in the Arab town of Jericho occupied the remains of an ancient synagogue. They were dislodged by soldiers after several hours. The 20-year-old Palestinian man was fatally beaten by masked youths in Silwan, an Arab village within Jerusalem's boundaries, city police spokesman Uzi Sandori said. Arab sources identified the victim as Yasin Mohammed Iskafi. Sandori said the slayers apparently suspected that Iskafi, who worked as a gardener for the city government, was collaborating with Israeli authorities. Residents of the village, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Iskafi was beaten with clubs embedded with nails. Late Sunday, police reported that an elderly Palestinian man in the Israeli-Arab village of Abu Ghoush near Jerusalem was stabbed in the chest by two masked assailants. ``(The assailants) told the old man he was suspected of collaborating with Israel,'' Sandori said. Iskafi's death brought to 240 the number of Palestinians killed by fellow Arabs in the 31-month uprising against the Israeli occupation. During the revolt, 723 Palestinians have been slain by Israeli soldiers and civilians and 45 Israelis have been killed by Palestinians. In the Gaza Strip's Rafah refugee camp, 10 Palestinians, ranging in age from 15 to 19, were shot in the legs by soldiers in renewed clashes between troops and stone-throwing youths, Arab hospital officials said. More than 40 Palestinians have been shot and wounded since clashes between soldiers and stone throwers resumed Friday in the refugee camp. Israeli newspapers reported the army was using Rafah as an experiment on how to reduce casualties at a time when Israel faces international criticism over its efforts to put down the Palestinian revolt. ``We don't use our weapons. Even when people are hit with stones, even when your life is threatened, you restrain,'' one lieutenant on patrol in Gaza City told Israeli television. His name was not given. The would-be Jewish settlers who took over the site of Jericho's ancient synagogue waved Israeli flags and signs saying ``Jericho is ours,'' Israel army radio reported. An army spokesman said the Israelis were ordered out because they did not have a permit to occupy the site. The policy of Israel's new right-wing government is to encourage Jews to settle in the occupied lands. However, new settlements have been limited following repeated complaints by the U.S. government, which views the Jewish enclaves as an obstacle to peace. Since the West Bank and Gaza were seized in the 1967 Middle East war, about 75,000 Israelis have moved into 130 settlements in the occupied territories. More than 1.7 million Palestinians live in the territories.

DOC.HEAD: Roman Catholic Leaders Urge Break In Salvadoran Peace Deadlock
DOC.TEXT: A Roman Catholic Church leader appealed to Salvadoran government and rebel negotiators at his Sunday services to break the deadlock in peace talks aimed at ending their country's decade-long civil war. ``Listen to the clamor of the people who demand peace. Give peace back to these long suffering Salvadorans,'' Roman Arrieta, San Jose's archbishop, said in the Mass homily. Salvadoran Archbishop Arturo Rivera Damas echoed Arrieta's words in a similar homily at Sacred Heart Church in San Salvador, warning that ``our country's social fabric continues tense and torn, and the mechanism of war continues with its friend-against-enemy ideology.'' Guerrilla leaders of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, also known as the FMLN, and delegates from President Alfredo Cristiani's rightist government attended Arrieta's Mass before entering into their third day of talks here. ``Let us hope this meeting brings an extraordinary advance in the search for peace and puts an end to so much pain, so many orphans and widows in El Salvador,'' Arrieta added. ``May God illuminate you so that you can attain the conquest of peace.'' The five-day session, the latest of several rounds since Cristiani took office in June 1989, has stalled over rebel demands that El Salvador's military be sharply reduced in numbers and purged of officers guilty of human rights violations. The rebels have also reiterated their long-standing demand that they have a say in naming the defense minister and the armed forces commander-in-chief. Cristiani has refused to agree to a rebel say in naming military officials. Guerrillas have threatened to renew fighting if the talks fail. Cristiani's government has also insisted the leftist guerrillas agree to an immediate cease-fire before military and political issues can be discussed. More than 72,000 people have been killed since the civil war began in October 1979. The majority of those slain were civilians suspected of being leftist sympathizers. ``Unfortunately, in this fratricidal war, both the soldiers and the guerrillas are of humble origin, and I ask myself why is it that the poor have to pay for these tragedies?'' Arrieta said. The Salvadoran Army, with about 54,000 members, is the second largest in Central America after Nicaragua's. The United States has been supporting a succession of governments during the guerrilla war. U.S. military and economic assistance to the Cristiani government totals $1 million a day.

DOC.HEAD: Peres Scores Key Victory in Party Vote
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 6-24 bgng `According to...' to ADD vote on separate candidacies; TRIMS; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Labor Party leader Shimon Peres scored an important political victory Sunday over his longtime rival, Yitzhak Rabin, who has been maneuvering to oust Peres as party head. ``I fell in love with my party again,'' declared a happy Peres, whose victory in a key vote came as a surprise even to some of his own supporters. ``The party and the country shall benefit from this victory,'' he said. The 1,400-member Labor central committee was called into session to consider demands by Rabin, Labor's No. 2 man, for a vote soon on the post of party chairman. Peres wanted it postponed until next year. The committee also voted on how to elect the chairman. Rabin wanted a candidate for prime minister separate from the party chairman. Peres opposed that demand. According to official results, about 54 percent of the 1,212 Labor members present supported Peres and decided to postpone the leadership contest, as opposed to Rabin's 46 percent. The vote was the same against establishing separate candidacies for prime minister and party chairman. Peres, a former prime minister, had argued for delaying the contest because he felt the center-left party should prepare for a battle with the rival Likud bloc, and not waste time on internal struggles. Just before official results of the vote were announced at the end of the seven-hour meeting here, dancing and singing supporters surrounded Peres, and many kissed and hugged him. Rabin has been jockeying to oust Peres since May, when Peres failed to form a Labor-led government after bringing down the shaky coaltion with Likud. The failure enabled Likud leader Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir to form his right-wing Cabinet in early June. ``I accept the majority decision,'' Rabin said after the vote. ``I thank the great number of central committee members who saw the need for a change, but the majority decides. I believe that from now on, the party should be united ... and organize itself as an opposition confronting Likud.'' The two leaders then briefly shook hands. Although both Rabin and Peres appealed for party unity, and Peres promised not to ``settle accounts,'' observers predicted that Labor will remain split and unable to present a strong opposition. ``We will see two organized and hostile camps, with leaders who hardly speak with each other ... a kind of prolonged war of attrition,'' said Israel radio's political observer, Hanan Cristal. ``Likud may forget about opposition, it will have an easy life in the government.'' Mordechai Gur, a senior Labor member and a Rabin supporter, said Peres' victory had ``weakened the party.'' ``We thought we should change the leadership to lead a strong, active opposition. With Peres it would be very difficult. We shall do our best, but I'm afraid it would not be as strong as it could have been,'' Gur said. Recent polls have consistantly indicated that Rabin, 68, is Israel's most popular leader. Also a former prime minister, he gained popularity for his tough stance as defense minister in the last government in dealing with the 31-month Palestinian uprising in the occupied territories. He also is remembered as chief of staff in the 1967 Middle East war when Israel captured the West Bank from Jordan and the Gaza Strip from Egypt. By contrast, the popularity of the Polish-born Peres, who turns 67 in 10 days, has been on the decline.

DOC.HEAD: Three Children Die in Morning Fire
DOC.TEXT: Three young children were killed and 23 people were injured when a three-alarm fire swept through an apartment building Sunday. The bodies of Caprisha Kennebrew, 6, her sister Duwatha, 4, and brother Devin, 3, were found in a bedroom in an apartment in the Harlem section of Manhattan, said fire spokesman Efrain Parrilla. More than 100 firefighters fought the blaze, which destroyed the Kennebrews' fourth-floor apartment and two others directly above on the fifth and sixth floors. Three other apartments were damaged by smoke. The fire was reported at 5:08 a.m. and under control by 6:30 a.m., Parrilla said. The children's father, Gaylord Dewese, 45, was in serious but stable condition with first- and second-degree burns on his face, arms and hands, New York Hospital's Cornell Burn Center said. The mother, Sondria Kennebrew, 40, was listed in stable condition at Harlem Hospital. A preliminary investigation determined that the fire was caused by Devin playing with matches in the bedroom while the mother, father and two sisters slept in the bed, Parrilla said. Quoting the city fire marshal, Parrilla said the boy has a history of playing with lighters, matches and the stove. He said Devin apparently woke his mother to tell her the bed was on fire and the father tried to put it out; the parents fled but the children were trapped in the room when the father shut the door and could not reopen it. An older daughter's boyfriend managed to open the door but was driven back by flames. Parrilla said 19 injured firefighters were treated for burns, heat exhaustion, cuts and bruises, and released. Two police officers also were treated for minor injuries, authorities said.

DOC.HEAD: Cellmate Says Wood Told Horrifying Tales of Desert Deaths
DOC.TEXT: Randy Wells says he remembers vividly the chilling, frequent conversations he had in prison with a cellmate now charged with murder in the killings of six young women found buried in the desert. ``The dude's crazy,'' Wells, 27, said in an interview last week with the Fort Worth Star-Telegram at the Eastland County Jail 90 miles west of Fort Worth. Wells said the man charged in the deaths, David Leonard Wood, told him he lured his victims to the desert with drugs and that he thinks he buried one victim alive. He said his information on Wood led to Wood's indictment. Wood claimed he tied his victims between a tree and the bumper of his truck, which he then used to stretch them before he raped and choked them, Wells said. Wood, a 33-year-old convicted rapist from El Paso, was indicted July 13 on murder charges in the slayings of six young women and teen-agers whose bodies were found in shallow, desert graves about 18 miles northeast of El Paso. The remains of the victims, ranging in age from 14 to 23, were found within a half-mile of each other between Sept. 4, 1987, and March 14, 1988. Some were runaways or prostitutes. Police were criticized for not responding more quickly to reports of their disappearances. Wells and Wood were cellmates for nearly two months at the Eastham Unit of the Texas Department of Corrections. Wood claimed to have killed 15 women, Wells said. ``He'd mumble in his dreams ... I knew he was tore up. He'd stay up for days,'' Wells said. Wells said Wood was particularly haunted by one victim. ``I think she was alive when he buried her. He was throwing dirt on her and it was running over her face,'' Wells said. ``When she breathed, the dirt came out around her nose and mouth.'' Wood frequently re-enacted ``dying quivers,'' he said. Wood had been a suspect in the killings for some time but police had insufficient evidence. Authorities said the indictment resulted from unspecified new information, but Wells said he was the source of that information. Neither El Paso investigators nor prosecutors would comment on Wells' statements or on whether he and another prison inmate were responsible for the new evidence that resulted in the indictment. Officials said they are under explicit orders not to talk about any aspect of the case. El Paso County First Assistant District Attorney Gonzalo Garcia said authorities are ``trying to keep the publicity down'' and are under a ``self-imposed gag order.'' But, according to the Star-Telegram, a letter on El Paso District Attorney Steve Simmons' stationery lauds cooperation in the case by Wells and James Carl Sweeney _ another prisoner who acted as Wood's jailhouse lawyer, Wells said. Wells' court-appointed lawyer, Gary Lewellen, said Wells' help did not come free. If Wells continues to cooperate and testifies against Wood, Wells will receive a 15-year prison sentence for forgery, Lewellen said. Prosecutors also would not pursue a capital murder charge against Wells. Eastland County District Attorney Emory Walton refused to confirm an agreement had been made with Wells. Wood is jailed in El Paso. He doesn't have an attorney for the serial murder case yet. Wood was arrested in October 1987 and five months later was convicted of sexual assault for a July 1987 rape. The victim testified at the trial that Wood took her to the desert near where bodies later were found and started digging a hole behind a bush, then raped her and left her naked in the desert. He was sentenced to 50 years in prison and fined $10,000. He had previous convictions for indecency with a child and rape. Wells also was on a return trip to prison when he met Wood. He had served time for burglary and was serving two years for theft.

DOC.HEAD: Man Shot to Death in Hotel Parking Lot
DOC.TEXT: An NBC employee was shot to death in his car in the parking lot of a hotel near Philadelphia International Airport.
