Frank Willis, 33, of Lawnside, N.J., was behind the wheel of his car shortly before 6 p.m. Saturday in the parking lot of the Days Inn hotel in southwest Philadelphia when a woman was seen banging on his car window, police said. The woman opened fire, shooting Willis in the left temple, back and hands, police said. The woman then fled in a nearby car. Homicide Detective Lawrence Nodiff said the assailant used a small-caliber weapon. He said police did not have a motive or suspect. Willis, who police said was in charge of daily operations for NBC's satellite distribution control in New York, had traveled to the hotel for an interview with a job recruiter.

DOC.HEAD: Task Force Gets First Look At Spotted Owls
DOC.TEXT: Federal officials trying to balance Northwest logging jobs against protecting the rare northern spotted owl got their first close-up look at the birds that officially become a threatened species Monday. ``They are a magnificent creature,'' said Jim Moseley, an assistant agriculture secretary and head of a committee meeting with timber industry leaders, government officials and environmentalists. ``And when you see something like that for the first time, and also to see an old-growth tree for the first time, it's an experience. It was extremely valuable to me to see that,'' Moseley said. Moseley's committee represents a federal inter-agency task force charged with devising a plan that balances owl interests against Northwest timber jobs. ``One of the things that's become clear to me: the issue goes beyond just the spotted owl,'' Moseley said. ``It is an old-growth issue. Clearly, cooperation between the agencies, between the state, between private landowners, is something that is ... recommended.'' The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service said last month the northern spotted owl would be listed as threatened under the federal Endangered Species Act, which means the government must come up with a protection plan. In the wake of that decision, the Bush Administration created the task force, which is to report by Sept. 1. Each nesting pair of owls needs large areas of undisturbed old-growth forest to survive. Bush has said he wants to balance the needs of timber communities against owl protection. Representatives of various groups emerged from meetings with the task force saying they had had a good hearing but doubted if the panel could accomplish anything significant. ``It's probably more wheel spinning, but it's necessary,'' said Mike Burrill, president of Burrill Lumber in Medford. ``They can't solve it on their own. The problems were created by laws passed by Congress.'' Doug Frank of the environmental group Friends of the Greensprings said an outside group like the task force is needed to find a compromise. ``When you have a dysfunctional family, you don't expect anybody in the family to solve the problem,'' Frank said. ``You expect somebody from outside to come in and help. On Saturday, Forest Service biologists led the task force onto the Butte Falls Ranger district of the Rogue River National Forest in the Cascade Range, where they saw an adult male spotted owl and an owlet living in a 14-acre forest patch surrounded by heavy logging, said spokeswoman Christina McGown. The owlet will be a ``sitting duck'' when it's time to leave the nest, because surrounding clearcuts will leave it vulnerable to its chief enemy, the great horned owl, said Forest Service biologist Mario Mamone. Scientists have suggested leaving swathes of trees uncut as protected corridors for owls and other wildlife. A panel of federal scientists has recommended placing 3 million acres of forest off-limits to logging to serve as owl habitats. The Forest Service has estimated that would cost 28,000 Northwest timber jobs over the next decade. Besides Moseley, the task force includes officials from the Interior Department, Environmental Protection Agency and Office of Management and Budget.

DOC.HEAD: Three Killed When Boats Collide in River
DOC.TEXT: Two speedboats collided in the Kings River in central California, killing all three people in one craft and injuring the two in the other. The collision occurred Saturday afternoon when the boat carrying the three turned in front of the other boat, driven by Mark Anthony Nichols, 33, of Ventura, said Tulare County sheriff's officers. A witness told deputies that Nichols swerved but could not avoid the other boat. The three people in the first boat all were dead at the scene, deputies said in a release read by Dispatcher Barbara Plummer. Police did not release their names but said they were a 32-year-old man, a 30-year-old woman and a 2-year-old child. Nichols suffered internal injuries and was listed in stable condition Sunday at Valley Medical Center in Fresno. His passenger, Brian Wallet, 24, also of Ventura, was treated for minor injuries and released. Police said the stretch of the Kings River where the accident occurred is narrow. The portion between Tulare and Fresno counties is popular for waterskiing and rafting in summer; on Saturday temperatures topped 100 degrees.

DOC.HEAD: Boulder Crashes Into Cabin at Estes Park, Killing Two
DOC.TEXT: A large boulder tumbled down a mountain at the mouth of a canyon early Sunday and crashed through a cabin, killing a man and a woman inside, an official said. Recent heavy rains were blamed for dislodging the boulder at the mouth of Big Thompson Canyon, said Larimer County Undersheriff Marv Schlageter. The boulder, estimated in size at 25 feet by 20 feet, tore through the cabin, knocking it off its foundation, and came to rest in front of the home about eight miles east of this Rocky Mountain resort. The undersheriff speculated that the couple was sleeping when the boulder hit sometime before 6:30 a.m. He said the names of the dead were being withheld pending notification of relatives.

DOC.HEAD: Legislators Meeting for Week to Discuss Issues
DOC.TEXT: Southern legislators arriving for a reception here were met by 15 people protesting a proposed hazardous waste facility. The protestors stood at the entrance to the palatial Biltmore House waving signs that read, ``Don't Waste Me and N.C.'' and ``Dirty Bucks Stop Here.'' The protest was directed at ThermalKEM, which has been selected to operate North Carolina's hazardous waste facility and which contributed $10,000 to the four-day legislative conference, said Lou Zeller of the Blue Ridge Environmental Defense League. ``We cannot afford 10 grand to rub elbows with our elected representatives,'' Zeller said. ``So we came to greet them with our call for waste reduction.'' ThemalKEM is listed in the conference program as a contributor, of an unspecified amount. The busloads of arriving legislators included some from Tennessee, Kentucky, South Carolina and Alabama, which have signed an interstate agreement with North Carolina to dispose of hazardous waste. The agreement calls for North Carolina to build a hazardous waste incinerator, a solvent recovery facility and a landfill by December 1991. The state has picked two potential sites for the complex in Granville, Rowan and Iredell counties. ``We think the deal was bad for North Carolina,'' said Jan Murphy, who lives about five miles from the potential site in Iredell County. ``Businesses need to be held responsible for their own waste.'' Lawmakers from nearly a third of the nation's legislatures are here this week to discuss issues from acid rain to redistricting. ``It's a great way for us to exchange ideas,'' said state Rep. Bob Hunter, a North Carolina Democrat who will be installed as chairman of the 44th annual Southern Legislative Conference Wednesday night. ``It gives legislators a chance to find out how other states are addressing some of the problems we all share.'' The North Carolina General Assembly, unable to get final action on a budget last week, adjourned for five days Friday to let members attend the conference. U.S. Sen. Charles Robb of Virginia will be the keynote speaker, and federal drug czar William Bennett is to speak on drug abuse in the South. Lawmakers from 16 states as far west as Texas and as far north as Maryland are to hold sessions on global warming, affordable housing, preserving rail corridors, long-term health care, redistricting and judicial activism. The idea of holding all Southern state presidential primaries on the same ``Super Tuesday,'' first tried in 1988, started with the legislative conference. The conference won't be all work. Legislators also can enjoy white-water rafting, golf, tennis, a mountain rodeo and a dinner dance.

DOC.HEAD: Senators Say Bush Should Avoid Abortion `Litmus Test'
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs grafs 6-7, ``Bush met xxx to update with time and roster of meeting
DOC.TEXT: Republican and Democratic senators alike on Sunday warned President Bush not to apply an anti-abortion ``litmus test'' as he searches for a successor to retired Supreme Court Justice William J. Brennan. ``If you have to have someone who wants to overturn Roe vs. Wade, it's going to be a blood bath getting the nomination confirmed, and the same is true on the other side,'' predicted Senate Republican leader Bob Dole of Kansas. ``There shouldn't be a single litmus test in picking a Supreme Court justice,'' Dole said on NBC-TV's ``Meet the Press'' program. Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., a member of the Senate Judiciary Committee, agreed it would be a mistake for Bush to base his choice on how prospective nominees views the high court's 1973 ruling in support of abortion rights. Leahy, appearing on CBS-TV's ``Face the Nation,'' said there was ``a very real question ... on whether the Senate would go along with'' a nominee who had been selected because he or she would vote a particular way on abortion. Bush met for 90 minutes with top lieutenants at the White House Sunday evening for an update on the search for Brennan's successor, but no decisions were made, White House spokeswoman Alixe Glen said. She said the meeting was attended by Vice President Dan Quayle, Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, presidential counsel C. Boyden Gray and White House chief of staff John Sununu. The brief session in the president's residence was called to fill in Bush on what had been done since the president convened a 75-minute meeting Saturday morning with the same three officials to get the ball rolling on the search. A source who was familiar with the meeting said afterward that it consisted of a review of material being gathered on all potential nominees rather than an attempt to narrow the field to a ``short list.'' The source spoke on condition of not being identified by name. Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, said Bush should look for someone who has ``a good judicial record, judicial temperament.'' Metzenbaum, appearing Sunday on ABC-TV's ``This Week With David Brinkley'' program, said he doesn't expect to like Bush's nominee, but added that there was an ``overwhelming likelihood that whomever the president sends up will be confirmed'' by the Senate. Bush has said he hopes to have a new justice seated on the court by October to succeed Brennan, who was a leading voice of liberalism on the Supreme Court for 33 years. Brennan, 84, announced his resignation Friday, citing his age and health. Most senators on Sunday declined to identify their choices for the high court. But Sen. Orrin Hatch, a Utah Republican who himself has been mentioned as a possible nominee, had a long list of possible contenders ready. ``I don't think I'm going to be selected, nor do I really want to be,'' Hatch said on ABC. Possible candidates mentioned by Hatch or elsewhere include: Solicitor General Kenneth W. Starr; federal appellate judges Edith H. Jones and Patrick E. Higginbotham of the 5th Circuit; William W. Wilkins Jr. of the 4th Circuit; and David Souter of the 1st Circuit. Other federal appellate judges mentioned are: Roger J. Miner and Ralph K. Winter Jr., both of the 2nd Circuit; J. Harvie Wilkinson III of the 4th Circuit; and Pamela A. Rymer, a former federal district judge whom Bush recently put on the 9th Circuit. There also has been speculation Bush might want to appoint the court's first Hispanic justice. Possible candidates would be Ferdinand Fernandez, a federal judge from California, and Ricardo Hinojosa, a federal judge from Texas. South Carolina Gov. Carroll Campbell and Sen. Strom Thurmond, R-S.C., called the White House on Saturday to lobby on behalf of Wilkins. ``The South deserves a seat on the Supreme Court,'' Campbell said in Columbia, S.C. But while senators were warning Bush not to use abortion as the overriding factor in his choice of a nominee, some observers were predicting that abortion would be a focal point in the Senate's confirmation debate. Conservatives have held a slim 5-4 majority on the court and liberals fear Brennan's successor could push the court further to the right and jeopardize the constitutional right to an abortion. Professor Eleanor Holmes Norton of the Georgetown University Law Center said both pro-choice and pro-life advocates regard abortion as a central issue in finding a successor to Brennan. ``You can bet your bottom dollar that sitting in the Senate are going to be men ... who will insist upon bringing out the views of the justice on this issue,'' Norton said on ABC. Norman Ornstein of the American Enterprise Institute, appearing on CBS, said if Bush picks someone who clearly opposes Roe vs. Wade, ``we are going to get that as the focal point of hearings that will be extended for a long time, probably ... right up into November.''

DOC.HEAD: Pygmy Sperm Whale Beaches, Dies
DOC.TEXT: A pygmy sperm whale that appeared emaciated and had ``cookie-cutter'' shark bites on its body died Sunday after beaching itself, officials said. The 10-foot-long male, weighing 800 to 1,000 pounds, was found around 8 a.m. Sunday by rangers from the Padre Island National Seashore on the south Texas coast. The mammal died in the early afternoon, said Tony Amos, a researcher at the University of Texas Marine Science Institute at Port Aransas. ``It looked a little emaciated to me, as if it hadn't been feeding,'' Amos said. ``There were a number of cookie cutter shark bites _ it's a shark that takes sort of cookie-cutter bites out of whales _ sort of like the mosquito of the whale world ,'' he said. ``But the bites themselves are not fatal.'' Amos said a number of the whale's teeth were broken, which is very unusual. The whale's body was iced down and trucked to Galveston, where researchers from Texas A&M University will try to determine what killed the animal and why it became stranded. The pygmy sperm whale is rare along the Texas coast, but Amos said this was not the first such stranding in the area. ``We get one about once every year,'' he said. The last one in the Corpus Christi-Port Aransas area washed ashore last October. None of those found stranded has survived.

DOC.HEAD: Walesa Wins Victory in Battle with Solidarity Rivals
DOC.TEXT: Lech Walesa won a victory Sunday over supporters of Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki in their battle for the allegiance of grassroots Solidarity groups. In recent weeks, the Solidarity movement has become split into two rival camps _ one supporting Walesa, the Solidarity chairman, and the other, Mazowiecki, the head of the government. The two camps have been battling for control of local Solidarity Citizens Committees, which have dominated Polish politics since the Communists lost power last year. On Sunday, delegates representing local Citizens Committees overwhelmingly rejected a proposal to form a centralized federation. Supporters of Mazowiecki had wanted the local committees to create a national federation to support his government, especially now that it is carrying out painful economic reforms. During Sunday's six-hour meeting, an overwhelming majority of the 136 delegates decided instead to hold occasional national conferences without creating a standing organization. Walesa, in a letter read at the opening of Sunday's meeting, made clear that he felt victory was his. ``A few weeks ago there was an attempt made to centralize the whole citizens movement. It is good that you did not agree to it. One must not forcibly create any kind of unclear unity,'' Walesa said. Walesa said he could not attend the meeting because he had broken his arm while on vacation and his doctor advised him not to travel. Mazowiecki said he couldn't attend because he had influenza. The local Citizens Committees sprang up to wage last year's successful parliamentary campaign that opened the way to a Solidarity-led government in August. They have been informally overseen by a 200-member national Citizens Committee of leading intellectuals and union activists who served at Walesa's invitation. Last month, 63 prominent Solidarity intellectuals and activists on the national committee broke ranks with Walesa. They called for disbanding the national body. Walesa's critics accused him of acting in an autocratic manner and trying to make the committees into tools for his widely expected campaign for president of Poland, a post now held by former Communist leader Wojciech Jaruzelski. The anti-Walesa group, finding itself shut out of control of the national Citizens Committee, had hoped to persuade local committees to form a national federation to support Mazowiecki. Last Monday, Walesa's opponents, including some major figures of the Solidarity movement, announced the formation of a center-left political movement, Democratic Action, which supports the Mazowiecki government. Democratic Action is expected to challenge a pro-Walesa political group, the Center Alliance, which was formed two months ago. In his letter, Walesa urged the local committees to get ready to choose their own candidates for upcoming free parliamentary elections, which are expected to be held by early spring. The committees' endorsement is important because most of the candidates backed by them have won in local and national elections. Walesa's remarks appeared to be setting the stage for a battle with his Solidarity rivals for control of the next Parliament, which could elect a new president. The split within Solidarity emerged after Walesa criticized the Mazowiecki government for what he considers the slow pace of political and economic reforms. Walesa's former allies accuse him of becoming a danger to democracy because he stirs emotions against the government at a time when it faces populist attacks for carrying out difficult economic reforms.

DOC.HEAD: Sewage Dumped Into New York Waterways As Fire Forced Plant Shutdown
DOC.TEXT: Raw sewage spilled into three rivers Sunday after an electrical fire forced the shutdown of a sewage plant serving Manhattan and the Bronx, a city spokesman said. Officials did not expect any public health problems due to the shutdown of the Wards Island plant, said Department of Environmental Protection spokesman Peter Cannavo. ``It's only a temporary problem,'' said Cannavo. ``We don't expect beaches to be affected because the flow of the harbor will carry it out to sea.'' Water samples were taken from the harbor, and beaches were patrolled as a precaution, Cannavo said. The fire occurred early Sunday at the Wards Island Water Pollution Control Plant, causing raw sewage to flow into the Harlem River, upper East River, and a small section of the Hudson River, he said. The fire caused a circuit breaker to fail at 4:10 a.m. on the main sewage pump, causing the system to shut down. The system was expected to be fully operational Sunday evening, Cannavo said. He said authorities would continue studying water in the harbor and local beaches Monday to determine the spill's impact. The Wards Island sewage plant handles more than 250 million gallons of wastewater daily from the west Bronx and Upper East Side of Manhattan. It is one of the largest of 14 plants that treat the city's raw sewage.

DOC.HEAD: `Skittish' Advertisers Cost ABC $14 Million in Ad Revenue
DOC.TEXT: ABC lost $14 million in advertising revenue last season to advertisers that boycotted programs they deemed offensive, network entertainment President Bob Iger said Sunday. ``It's a sorry state of affairs when advertisers are acting as skittish as they are,'' Iger told a news conference attended by television critics. ``The networks get the heat, but I really think it should be the advertisers.'' The lost revenue was slightly more than 1 percent of ABC's total advertising revenues of $1 billion for this year, Iger said. Iger declined to name the advertisers who withdrew their commercials, and said the $14 million figure represented the first time ABC had counted such lost revenue since he took over as programming chief 16 months ago. His remarks were in response to continued questioning about ABC's refusal to rerun an episode of ``thirtysomething'' that showed two gay men in bed talking about friends who had died from AIDS. Iger's ``economic'' decision to shelve the installment was labeled as ``cowardice'' by gay and lesbian groups that have launched a letter-writing protest. Iger said Saturday he pulled the episode because half of ``thirtysomething'' advertisers boycotted its first showing last season, costing the network more than $1 million. Other shows that suffered a similar fate last season included an episode of ``Roseanne'' that focused on teen-age drinking, Iger said. One sponsor pulled out of that program, Iger said. Thirty-second commercial spots on ``Roseanne'' usually range from $300,000 to $400,000, according to trade publications. Iger's question-and-answer period with television critics also covered ABC's upcoming fall and spring schedules. With six new shows, ABC has a smaller number of fall programs to launch than CBS or NBC. ``It makes the task at hand easier,'' Iger said. Of those, ``Cop Rock'' is probably ABC's best hope, Iger said. The new show about singing police officers has drawn a decidedly mixed response from ABC's affiliated stations.

DOC.HEAD: ABC Announces Two Replacement Shows for Spring Schedule
With AM-ABC President
DOC.TEXT: ABC announced two new shows Sunday for its spring replacement schedule. ``STAT,'' by producer Danny Arnold of ``Barney Miller,'' will feature an ensemble comedy cast in an urban hospital emergency room. ``The Principal,'' starring Randy Quaid as a schoolteacher who reluctantly becomes principal, also features comedian Jonathan Winters as Quaid's father. ``Principal'' is from independent producers Marcy Carsey and Tom Werner, whose Carsey@Werner Co. is responsible for such hits as ``Roseanne'' and ``The Cosby Show.'' ``Anything But Love,'' canceled at the end of last season but then given a reprieve as a 1991 spring replacement series, will have guest appearances by John Ritter, the former star of ``Hooperman'' and ``Three's Company,'' ABC also announced. Bruce Weitz, who played the snarling undercover cop Belker on ``Hill Street Blues,'' also will join ``Anything But Love'' as a new employee of the fictional Chicago magazine where characters played by actress Jamie Lee Curtis and comic Richard Lewis work.

DOC.HEAD: Cleanup Delayed at Site of Explosion
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `One of ...,' to CORRECT that both patients at University Hospital in critical condition, sted one fair and one critical.
DOC.TEXT: Federal and state investigators on Sunday delayed the cleanup of a chemical plant leveled by a deadly explosion last week. BASF Corp. had hoped fire officials could begin removing hundreds of barrels of chemicals from its plant site on Sunday, said quality assurance manager Ron Leisner. ``But there's a lot of consideration that has to be made in a situation like this,'' he said. ``We don't even have access to some of the sites yet.'' Thursday's blast killed one man, injured at least 68 people and shattered glass in buildings surrounding the plant on the city's north side. Buildings in the nine-acre complex were leveled or gutted. Both patients at University Hospital remained in critical condition Sunday. A third person was in critical condition at Bethesda Hospital. Teams from the Occupational Safety and Health Administration and the state and federal environmental protection agencies were on the scene, Leisner said. The investigators want ``to make sure the area is secure before we get too deep into the cleanup and removal of any of the damaged materials,'' he said. Some asbestos was found in the building debris, but no airborne particles, Leisner said. He said the area will continue to be monitored for asbestos and other dangers. Some of the drums to be removed contain hazardous materials and could explode if punctured or ignited, said William Murphy, OSHA's area director. He said the Ohio Environmental Protection Agency will not allow those to be removed from the site, and that any that are potentially explosive will be moved to an isolated area. Officials barricaded the area after a rekindled fire was discovered next to some barrels Saturday, but the fire was extinguished and all but a portion of one road was reopened. The plant, owned by Inmont Corp. until 1985, was cited four times after recent OSHA inspections. State inspectors found eight waste storage problems in a Feb. 27 check. Investigators said they could not be sure whether waste management problems were a factor in the blast. Company officials said preliminary indications were that it was caused by a piece of equipment that overheated.

DOC.HEAD: Resident of Another Key Wins Look-alike Contest
DOC.TEXT: It took him three tries, but Fred Burnham finally won the Ernest Hemingway Look-Alike Contest on Sunday. Burnham came from Longboat Key, up the Gulf Coast near Sarasota, to win the 10th annual contest at Hemingway's favorite Key West bar, Sloppy Joe's. He attributed his victory to his shaggy gray beard, reminiscent of the one the late Nobel and Pulitzer prize-winning novelist sported in his mature years. ``The first year I didn't even qualify,'' said Burnham, owner of a construction cleanup firm. ``But the camaraderie and good times kept me coming back.'' This year's competition drew 63 look-alikes from as far away as Santa Rosa, Calif., to the contest, part of Key West's Hemingway Days celebration. In the 1930s, Hemingway wrote some of his most famous works at his Key West home, now a museum. They include ``For Whom the Bell Tolls,'' ``A Farewell to Arms,'' ``The Snows of Kilimanjaro'' and ``Green Hills of Africa.'' To honor his literary genius, each year the festival coordinates a short story competition. ``If You Can Hear This,'' by Pamela Ball of Tallahassee, bested this year's 620 entries to win $2,000 in cash and prizes. Her fictional story explores a relationship between a woman and the voice of a radio announcer.

DOC.HEAD: Employees Say State Doesn't Realize Hardship of Late Checks
DOC.TEXT: Paychecks to thousands of state employees are overdue by up to 12 days, and unpaid workers said Sunday that Oklahoma officials don't realize the severity of their plight. ``There are people whose kids are getting hungry,'' said Terry Delaplain, a mental health aide at the state Griffin Memorial Hospital in Norman, and mother of a 14-year-old son. ``I have food, and will have food in the house until Tuesday or Wednesday, but after that ...'' ``I don't think they're taking it seriously and I don't think they have a concept of the problems it's causing,'' said Gerald May, another mental health aide there. ``They're not giving straight answers. They're not giving assistance.'' State finance spokesman Harry Culver said Sunday that prospects were good for some overdue paychecks to be released Monday. State payroll processors worked until about midnight Friday and Saturday and came in early both days to get the checks out despite processing problems caused by a switch to a new computer system, Culver said. As of Friday evening, about 13,500 paychecks out of a state payroll of more than 60,000 workers were overdue, some by as much as 12 days, Culver said. ``They told us all week we'd get our Friday paychecks late Friday,'' said Eric Holmes, a fire and safety officer at Griffin Memorial. ``They told us Friday it'd be Monday, and Friday evening they told us they'd be out Tuesday.'' ``There's one guy who called and said, ``I've only got gas to make it to work one time, so you call me that one time to come get my check,''' he said. Jeanne Devlin said she and 55 other Department of Tourism and Recreation employees got their July 13 paychecks on Thursday. ``We were told every day we were going to get it, and I went in there every day and had to reassure my day-care person,'' Devlin, managing editor of the state's Oklahoma Today magazine, said by telephone from Stillwater. ``I find it embarrassing.'' May resorted to a pawnshop to keep his checking account solvent after, assured he would be paid Friday, he wrote checks for bills. ``I got $60 for my VCR and $45 for my guitar,'' he said by telephone. The state issued a letter at midweek for workers to take to creditors vouching that overdue bills were all but out of the workers' control. But workers said the state hadn't issued the letter on state letterhead. ``They gave us a little voucher that's supposed to pacify the creditors,'' Holmes said. ``Well, it doesn't pacify the grocery store, the gas station or anybody else like that. And I doubt if it pacifies the creditors.'' The state employees' credit union is making instant loans available to workers whose paychecks are overdue. But Ms. Delaplain said some of her co-workers make about $5 an hour _ too little to have made joining the credit union worthwhile. Of those workers, Culver said, ``Well, I suppose they should try to make other arrangements.'' The state is trying to come up with numbers that workers can call for advice about their financial predicament, he said. ``I don't know anything that can be done, other than fix the computer problem,'' he said. ``I guess, you know, each one is a different case, but certainly our complete concern and sympathy goes out for anybody in this situation.''

DOC.HEAD: Partial Eclipse In Hawaii A Prelude To Total Eclipse Next Year
DOC.TEXT: Many Hawaii residents got glimpses through breaks in the clouds of a partial solar eclipse, a prelude to a rare total eclipse that will occur in the islands in less than a year. More than 2,000 people showed up Saturday evening at Bishop Museum, borrowing from a supply of mirror-like safety filters to watch the moon block the sun. At its peak shortly after 6 p.m,. 62.2 percent of the sun was blanked out. Scientists for several days had been advising residents to avoid looking directly at the sun, warning that permanent eye damage could result. Besides the opaque filters and welder's goggles used at the museum, simple pinhole cameras were set up to reflect the eclipse on the back wall of a box. The big show will occur on the morning of July 11, 1991. Hawaii Island, the southernmost in the chain, will experience a total eclipse for four minutes, one of the longest in the United States this century and the last total eclipse in the United States until 2017.

DOC.HEAD: Jazz Pianist, Joe Turner, Dies in Paris
DOC.TEXT: Jazz pianist Joe Turner, who played with such greats as Louis Armstrong and Benny Carter, has died of a heart attack in Paris. He was 82. Turner, who died Saturday at suburban Montreuil hospital, helped make famous the ``stride style'' of piano playing. His work earned him a place in jazz history beside pianists like James P. Johnson, Fats Waller, Art Tatum and Willie ``The Lion'' Smith. Since 1962, he had played in La Calavados, a night club on the Champs Elysees. Turner was born Nov. 3, 1907, in Baltimore. At 18, he left the city to pursue his musical career in New York. A big break came in 1928, when he was hired to play in the Benny Carter orchestra. He joined Armstrong's group in 1930. Turner used to play in Harlem clubs, and in 1935 he replaced Art Tatum, who was ill. He performed with jazz singer Adelaide Hall and went on a European tour with her. Drafted during World War II, Turner played piano in the U.S. Army orchestra directed by Sy Oliver. After the war, he settled in Europe and played with Rex Stewart. He had lived in Paris since 1962. No information was immediately available about survivors or funeral arrangements.

DOC.HEAD: Man Arrested in Microchip Case
DOC.TEXT: A man was arrested in the theft of $321,000 worth of state-of-the-art computer microchips, the FBI announced Sunday. Bernard Pornaras of Hollister, Calif., was arrested Saturday night, the FBI's top agent in Honolulu, Jim R. Freeman, said in a statement. Pornaras is wanted in Santa Clara County, Calif., along with two other men in the theft of the chips from a northern California company, Freeman said. The three allegedly planned to sell 642 chips worth $500 each in the Far East, Freeman said. The chips increase computers' memory capacities. A second man, Raymond Reynolds, was arrested in California and the third suspect, Michael Arnold, remains at large, the agent said. Each of the three was charged in a criminal complaint filed Thursday in Santa Clara County with interstate transportation of stolen property, which carries a maximum sentence of 10 years in prison. Pornaras was being held pending an appearance before a U.S. magistrate, Freeman said. The arrests were the result of a joint investigation by the FBI, the Internal Revenue Service, the state Department of Motor Vehicles and the Santa Clara County district attorney's office.

DOC.HEAD: South Korea Willing To Negotiate North Korean Preconditions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with government ministers announcing they are ready to negotiate with North Korea; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: South Korea is ready to negotiate North Korean preconditions for opening the border to free travel between the rival nations, South Korean officials announced Monday. The decision follows a major policy speech Friday by President Roh Tae-woo, who proposed to North Korea that the common border be opened for five days in August on a trial basis to allow free travel for residents of the two sides. He said open borders could lead talks on eventual unification of the Koreas. Communist North Korea immediately dismissed Roh's proposal as ``fraudulent propaganda.'' It said South Korea must first tear down ``concrete walls'' allegedly built along its border, end national security laws banning pro-Communist activity, and release dissidents jailed for promoting unification. Three Cabinet ministers Monday proposed that inter-Korea talks be held Friday to discuss the North Korean preconditions. The heavily fortified border between the two Koreas is tightly sealed, and more than 1.5 million troops are stationed on either side behind concrete bunkers and barbed wire. There is no mail, travel or other communication between the two sides. Justice Minister Lee Jong-nam, Defense Minister Lee Sang-hoon and National Unification Minister Hong Sung-chul held a joint news conference to announce the South Korean policy. ``In order to open the border and realize grand national exchanges, we are ready to discuss any problems related to it,'' the unification minister said on national radio and television. Pro-Western South Korea and communist North Korea were divided at the end of World War II and fought the Korean war from 1950 to 1953. They are technically still at war because no peace treaty was signed. In their announcement Monday, Hong and other ministers said the discussions should include any problems either side would raise. They noted that North Korea has a number of legal and systematic barriers to free travel. The North Koreans had also demanded that South Korean radical students and dissidents be allowed to attend a ``pan-national congress'' the North plans to hold at the border village of Panmunjom on Aug. 15 to promote unification. The unification minister, Hong, said the Seoul government would support the Aug. 15 rally if the South Korean delegation would include ``representatives of all walks of life.'' The North invited only dissident and radical student leaders from the South. Hong also said his government would allow a cross-border march by any organization on the two sides. South Korea banned such marches by its dissident groups in the past. The justice minister said South Korea can discuss preconditions North Korea has set in connection of the border opening, but he noted that Pyongyang also has harsh national security laws and human rights problems. Several prominent South Korean dissident leaders have been jailed for making unauthorized trips to North Korea in violation of national security law. North Korea has demanded the release of the jailed dissidents and the repeal of the law under which they were punished. The justice minister said North Korea also has laws calling for capital punishment for those supporting South Korea and its constitution states that the No. 1 goal of the North is bringing Communism to the South. Quoting reports by international human rights groups, Lee said North Korea is holding 152,000 political prisoners at 12 concentration camps. The prisoners included former prime minister Lee Kun-mo, former vice presidents Kim Chang-bong and Park Kum-chul, and ex-national security chief Kim Byung-ha. The minister also said North Korea imposes tight domestic travel restrictions. The North's 21 million people cannot travel beyond the boundary of a country they live in without prior government approval, he said. The defense minister proposed an on-site joint investigation of the alleged ``concrete walls'' in the South, along with similar barriers which he claimed exist along the northern sector of the border. He said the ``walls'' are in fact a series of tank traps built along several sections of the 155-mile border to block a possible North Korean invasion. North Korea also has anti-tank barriers along the border, the minister said. The defense minister also demanded a joint investigation of four ``invasion tunnels'' allegedly dug by North Korea under the Demilitarized Zone separating the two Koreas. North Korea has denied digging the tunnels.

DOC.HEAD: Smoke From Alaska Wildfires Creating Health, Driving Hazards
DOC.TEXT: Wildfires burned over more than 900,000 acres of Alaska on Sunday, producing smoke that hampered firefighting and triggered an air-quality alert in Fairbanks and much of the rest of the interior. Visibility at the Riley Creek Visitors Center at Denali National Park, 120 miles south of Fairbanks and Alaska's top tourist attraction, dropped to a quarter-mile at times over the weekend. ``The park is up and running as usual but they're cautioning people not to exert themselves and to spend time indoors,'' said Park Service spokesman John Quinley. People in Fairbanks were given similar warnings. No injuries or serious damage has been reported. Smoke from wildfires that have already burned more than a million acres made it impossible to get accurate estimates of the sizes of some blazes, Quinley said. Thick smoke grounded some aircraft used in fighting the 54,000-acre Tok River fire, said Trish Hogervorst-Rukke, a spokeswoman with Alaska's inter-agency fire information center. But the smoke also held down temperatures in the interior and pushed up the humidity, reducing the intensity of the blazes. The Tok River fire, started by lightning three weeks ago, remained the state's most labor-intensive blaze, occupying 789 firefighters. Officials estimate that firefighting statewide is costing $700,000 a day. The Beaver fire, named for a village on the Yukon River, remained Alaska's largest; on Sunday it was burning a 10-by-48-mile section of spruce forest, said Hogervorst-Rukke. Fires along the Alaska Highway reduced visibility to less than 2 miles in a wide region north of Tok to Fairbanks. Authorities said Alaska firefighting crews were also sent to the Canadian border village of Old Crow, where about 280 people were evacuated because of fire near the Porcupine River. A fire 25 miles northeast of King Salmon was estimated at 1,100 acres and was being fought with specially designed planes from Canada that fly low, scooping water from lakes and depositing it over fires. The Kanuti Flats fire, about 140 miles north of Fairbanks, was burning 100,000 acres on Sunday and was within two miles of the trans-Alaska oil pipeline. Authorities were monitoring the fire but not fighting it. Authorities said there was no danger to the pipeline, which Quinley said isburied beneath the tundra near where the fire is burning.
